Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2011 12:54PM jkp wrote: Hooray for you - DFB!!!  Congratulations!  Enjoy your holidays!
Posts.Title: Excisional biopsy on Monday jkp dfb1963

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2011 04:02AM jkp wrote: Thanks for all of the support.  Today has been a crummy day.  I feel like I can't wait another minute.  It's awful.  I just want to get on with my life - cancer or not.  If you are there, show yourself!  If not, get out of my life (and for G-d's sake, get out of my head!!!!)
Posts.Title: Excisional biopsy on Monday jkp dfb1963

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2011 09:36AM jkp wrote: I'm baaaack!  Been home for a few hours sleeping off all the meds.  Cannot overstate how AWESOME it was to have the valium.  They gave it to me after I had gotten checked in and signed all the papers.  Worked really fast.  Made me feel kind of stoned and sleepy.  The nurse had a bit of trouble getting my IV going and I barely even noticed.  Here's the crazy part - the wire localization was a piece of cake.  Really!  I did feel the stinging of the numbing injection, but only for about 4-5 seconds.  After I was numbed, he put the wire in (didn't look!) and I felt NO PAIN AT ALL.  Whew!  At one point he was pushing really hard (don't know why), but there was still no pain.  Because mine was an excisional, I was asleep for the biopsy itself.  Woke up in recovery and am doing fine.  I am staying ahead of the pain - if I start to feel a twinge, I take something.  They gave me vicodin, but I am going easy on it and only taking one.  Dr. says I can call on Thursday after 2:30 for results.  All in all, not nearly as bad as I was thinking it might be.
Posts.Title: Excisional biopsy on Monday jkp dfb1963

Posts.Content: jkp wrote: Well, It's almost time.  Seems like I have been waiting forever, but on Monday I will be through the next step.  I wanted to send out some positive news to people who have been reading about difficulties with wire biopsies.  I just talked to the pre-op nurse at my hospital.  She told me I could ask the surgeon to order a small dose of valium before they do the wire localization, which of course I did immediately!  That made me feel a lot better. Hugs to all of you that had a hard time with the procedure.  Hopefully all will go smoothly for me and then a few days later I will have some answers.  Any other biopsies in the next few days/weeks?  We can hold each other up! "Are we having fun yet?" Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Excisional biopsy on Monday jkp dfb1963

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2011 02:03PM jkp wrote: Thanks, sistas!  DFB, make sure you check in and let us know how it went.  I'll be thinking of you on Thursday (my bday!!!)
Posts.Title: Excisional biopsy on Monday jkp dfb1963

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2011 10:40AM jkp wrote: Sorry if you have been following me on other threads, as this will be a re-post.  I'm going to try to put it in all the places where I had significant conversations going with a group: Good news from the waiting room - BENIGN!   BENIGN!   BENIGN!!!  Fibroadenoma - as originally suspected. I can't seem to wipe the smile off my face.  Tomorrow is my birthday, and this is the best present I have ever gotten  I remember reading that someone mentioned not seeing many benign results on the board.  I think maybe a lot of people feel bad coming back to report good news when others are suffering so. (I thought about that too). But I AM going to report it, because I know that many who are waiting WILL get benign results and they need to see that it has happened before and will happen again.  I am forever grateful to the brave and wonderful women who I have "met" on this board.  I have never experienced so much good information, love, and support.  You are all in my thoughts and prayers.  God bless you all. -Julie
Posts.Title: Excisional biopsy on Monday jkp dfb1963

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2011 05:29AM jkp wrote: Had excisional biopsy on Monday.  Waiting for results tomorrow afternoon.  Argggggggggh!  The waiting....
Posts.Title: So who is waiting for test results/ or having test Tenmom Kimberly5307

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2011 08:42AM jkp wrote: Awww, Peg, sharing your pain and frustration.  I know how hard the waiting is (I'm awaiting test results as we speak).  Let me address a couple of your concerns, though, and see if I can make you feel any better: 1)  If you are having a fine needle aspiration, there is a good chance the doctor thinks the mass is filled with fluid and therefore, probably only a cyst (not cancer).  That is good news to start with! 2)  I was surprised as the number of young women on the board too, but remember that most of the ones who are writing are the ones who ended up gettting a cancer diagnosis.  The statistic is that about 80% of biopsied tumors are NOT canceous.  Most of those women aren't on the board writing about their experiences. 3) If the doctor suggests a biopsy, that is the prudent thing to do.  If you have cancer and don't get the biopsy, it doesn't mean that the cancer isn't there.  It just means that you won't know about it until it gets worse.  The sooner things are caught, the better the outcome is likely to be. 4)  You must be extra scared knowing that your mother went through this, and so young.  You are very brave to be taking the next step and finding out what lies ahead.  I will be thinking benign (not cancerous) thoughts for you.  Since I had my biopsy yesterday, I'm probably going to be hanging around today.  If you post on the board, I'll probably answer pretty quickly.   Wishing you calm peaceful thoughts, Julie
Posts.Title: 34 years old...biopsy tomorrow...scared PegInTX Tenmom

Been wondering what that might be.  I have a suspected fibroadenoma (11mm) and am waiting to see the surgeon to talk about biopsy options.  The tingling is in the same area as the lump. Anyone know more about this?
Posts.Title: Anyone have a tingly feeling in their breast? Kite jkp

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2011 09:43AM jkp wrote: I respect your decision - you have to go with your gut feeling.  In my line of work, I am often faced with really difficult decisions that can effect the lives of children.  I will never forget the time I asked a (more seasoned) colleague for her opinion on a difficult choice I needed to make.  Her response was this: there is no right or wrong answer.  The most important factor that can guide you is - which choice will allow you to sleep tonight?  Best wishes for your continued health and peace.  -Julie

Posts.Title: NEW: I need a waiting buddy skapaya skapaya

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2011 06:50PM jkp wrote: I'm with you all!  From the beginning of feeling the lump it has been over a month and there are days where I think I am not going to make it through the waiting.  I've been mammoed and ultrasounded.  Today I finally got the biopsy and should have results by Thursday.  Chicky - I was ROFL when I saw you talking about the "titty clinic".  (And normally, that is one of my least favorite words.)  But I agree, you've got to have some silliness here or you aren't going to make it. So in the same spirit, I will repeat a story that I saw here on a different thread.  I have no idea who said it, or I would give credit and link it, because she told the story much better.  But we can certainly all use a laugh, so here it goes: Apparently the woman was newly recovering from an unilateral mastectomy.  Since she was feeling better, her family decided to take her out to dinner at a BBQ place.  They were placing their orders and her son said to the waitress "I'll have half a rack".  The woman and her husband proceeded to crack up uncontrollably.  hahahahahaa ...half a rack.  With dire circumstances,, twisted sense of humor develops.  But I'd rather laugh than cry, so there you have it!
Posts.Title: NEW: I need a waiting buddy skapaya skapaya

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2011 02:10PM jkp wrote: LOL, skapaya.  I had never touched my breasts so much in my life as I did when I was waiting !!!   Of course it makes *logical* sense not to worry about it when you have no control, but - come on - what is logical about this whole thing???  Try to be good to yourself and soon (but not nearly soon enough) you will have some more answers.

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2011 07:38PM jkp wrote: I just had a fibroadenoma removed a few weeks ago.  Now that the emotion is out of the picture, I think I can look back and realize that it has grown over the past couple of years (I am 42).  I always had the feeling of being "poked" by my underwire bras and didn't understand why no one could make a bra that didn't poke me!  When the annoyance turned into specific pain, I had it checked out.  Uh...guess where the fibroadenoma was?  Yep, right where the underwire hits the underarm area. Happy to report that everything went really well and am ready to start wearing real bras again.  (Have been wearing sports bras for the past 2 months and they really aren't very flattering!)  Best of luck to you in getting your concerns resolved.  I feel your pain!
